scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification has been included in a national catalogue from a Member State whose NIF is fully aligned with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to NIFO factsheets.
statement:
The standard or specification is included in 3 national catalogues. They belong to Member States which comply with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to the NIFO factsheets. (e.g. the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden).  
                                                                                         
See:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

criterion_description: The standard or specification facilitates the publication of public data as open data.
statement:
HTTP is a transfer protocol which has been developed to exchange the information through computer networks. It is supporting the first level of maturity defined by Tim Berners Lee-s 5 star schema for Open data, "Make your data available" 

See
https://5stardata.info/en

criterion_description: All stakeholders have the opportunity to contribute to the development of the specificationÂ
statement:
IETF has a formal review and approval so that all the relevant stakeholders can formally appeal or raise objections to the development and approval of specifications.

Each distinct version of an Internet standards-related specification is published as part of the "Request for Comments" (RFC) document series. This archival series is the official publication channel for Internet standards documents and other publications.

During the development of a specification, draft versions of the document are made available for informal review and comment by placing them in the IETF's "Internet-Drafts" directory, which is replicated on a number of Internet hosts. This makes an evolving working document readily available to a wide audience, facilitating the process of review and revision.

See:
https://www.ietf.org/standards/process/ 
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2026

criterion_description: The standard or specification is licensed on a (F)RAND basis
statement:
Like all the IETF standards, HTTP is a free and open technical specification, built on IETF standards and licenses from the Open Web Foundation. HTTP 1.1 is therefore licensed on a royalty-free basis.                                                                    

See:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3668                                                                                                                                        https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616

statement: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol ) is a Transfer Protocol used for communication over a computer network. It is used to transfer data between administrations.

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. criterion_description: The standard or specification eases the implementation of the once-only principle.
statement:
The once-only principle is an e-government concept that aims to ensure that citizens, institutions, and companies only have to provide certain standard information to the authorities and administrations once.

HTTP is a protocol developed to exchange information over the internet environment. Thus, HTTP eases the implementation of once-only principle by means of allowing administration's stakeholders reduce interaction.    
                                                                           
See: http://www.toop.eu/sites/default/files/D21_Federated_OOP_Architecture.pdf

criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters e-accessibility.
statement: The purpose of HTTP is not related to  e-accessibility. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable specification.

The extension of HTTP; HTTPS, uses other protocols for securing communications.

criterion_description: The standard or specification can be mapped to the EIRA.
statement:
HTTP is already associated to an EIRA ABB in the European Library Of Specifications (ELIS). More specifically, HTTP can define the interoperability aspects of the "Network Service", "Network Component" "Private Network" and "Public Network" ABBs of the EIRA Technical View.

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/elis/distribution/eliscataloguev100betaxlsx

statement: No mechanisms assessing the compliance of implementations with the specification have been found.

criterion_description: The standard or specification has been selected for its use in a EU cross-border project or initiative after agreed identification and assessment.
statement:
Any cross-border project using internet, uses HTTP.

An interesting example is the TESTA network service â which stands for Trans European Services for Telematics between Administrations â provides a European backbone network for data exchange between a wide variety of public administrations. It is an ISA2 solution which has been designed to support the needs for a whole range of application architectures relying on protocols such as HTTPS. 

See:
https://ec.europa.eu/isa2/solutions/testa_en

criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in a catalogue of standards at national level.
statement:
HTTP is included within at least 11 Member States' ICT Catalogues (e.g. Spain, France, Sweden)

See CAMSS List of Standards:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in a catalogue of standards at EU level.
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, HTTP has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision and included in the European list of ICT Standards for e-procurement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in an interoperability agreement established between organisations involved in European public service provision.
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, HTTP has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision. During the evaluation process, all the Member States are invited to share their doubts. The positive evaluation of HTTP and its identification is considered an interoperability agreement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is compliant with a European standardisation regulation (e.g. regulation 1025/2012 on European standardisation).
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, HTTP has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

statement: The purpose of HTTP is not related  to the modelling of business processes. Therefore, this criterion is not applicable to the specification.

criterion_description: The standard or specification defines a cross-sector reusable data model.
statement: HTTP does not defines a cross-sector reusable data model. HTTPS is a transfer protocol used for secure communication over a computer network.

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters the publication of data as Linked Open Data.
statement:
HTTP is an internet protocol for the data exchange over an Internet network. It supports the first level of maturity defined in the Tim Berners-LeeÂ´s  5 stars Open Data deployment scheme, "Make your data accessible on the web". 

See: 
https://5stardata.info/en/

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is available for free on at least one national or European platform.
statement:
HTTP 1.1 is available on Joinup, the collaborative platform for Reusable IT Solutions funded by the European Commission.

See:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/http-over-tls
